customer_addr:
2976 E. State St Suite 120 #211
Eagle, ID 83616

citations.narrative:
Three parakeets in the walk-in aviary were killed during feeding interactions with guests. The aviary is designed to allow
the public to come in and have an interactive experience with the parakeets, feeding them from hand-held plates that
contain seed provided by the facility. There are about 150 parakeets in the enclosure. People are seated on benches as
they feed the birds. Even though only a small amount of seed falls on the floor during feeding, it is enough to cause large
numbers of birds to forage around people's feet and the surrounding floor area. Quests are instructed to keep their feet
and heals on the floor and shuffle as they walked in and out of the enclosure. Despite these precautions, the presence of
birds on the floor around people's feet led to these three incidents.
***On June 5, 2025, a guest dropped their cellphone and it landed on a parakeet resulting in its death.
***On July 5, 2025, an employee tripped over a guest's foot and landed on a parakeet resulting in its death.
***Within the last couple weeks, an employee stepped backwards while leading a group of guests out the aviary and
stepped on parakeet resulting in its death. The exact date of this incident is not known because it was not recorded.
During public exhibition, care must be taken so that there is minimal risk of harm to the birds with sufficient distance
and/or barriers between the birds and the general viewing public to assure the safety of animals.
To be corrected by: October 14, 2025
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
Additional Inspectors:
HEATHER COLE n

narrative:
2.131(c)(1)  Critical
   
Handling of animals. 
Three parakeets in the walk-in aviary were killed during feeding interactions with guests. The aviary is designed to allow

***On June 5, 2025, a guest dropped their cellphone and it landed on a parakeet resulting in its death.  
***On July 5, 2025, an employee tripped over a guest's foot and landed on a parakeet resulting in its death. 
***Within the last couple weeks, an employee stepped backwards while leading a group of guests out the aviary and

and/or barriers between the birds and the general viewing public to assure the safety of animals.

This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative. 
 
Additional Inspectors:
